Cards, Cats skirmish before football game

The two sides met near midfield twice, pushing and shoving.

Cards, Cats skirmish before football game

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 3:21 p.m. EST November 29, 2014
Buy Photo

UK's Jared Leet throws up the Louisville "L" before kickoff Saturday.(Photo: By Matt Stone/The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

1 CONNECT 12 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The University of Louisville and Kentucky football teams didn't make it to kickoff at noon Saturday without delivering some pregame hits.

Ahead of the first regular-season finale version of the Governor's Cup rivalry, both teams (and their coaches) got together near midfield twice, pushing, shoving and jawing around the Cardinal bird logo.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Reggie Bonnafon leaves Louisville game with knee injury

When U of L players came out to warm up just past 11 a.m. -- UK's players were already on the field -- the two sides met for the first time. The confrontation was brief but had the few fans already in Papa John's Cardinal Stadium out of their seats.

Who started it? Who knows.

Cats-Cards involved in pregame skirmish https://t.co/LIYodvmYa2

— TheCatsPause247 (@TheCatsPause247) November 29, 2014

Not long afterward, more UK players came on the field to warm up, running past the Cards with some visible taunts. It started again, involving most of both coaching staffs as well. This skirmish was bigger, and it all happened on the Cards' side of the 50-yard line.

Who started it? Count the Cats as the instigators this time.

UK assistant coach Dan Berezowitz and UofL head coach Bobby Petrino scuffle at midfield prior to the #UKvsUofL game pic.twitter.com/JVEWLfYM51

— Michael Reaves (@MichaelMReaves) November 29, 2014

Officials will look this sort of thing over and deem before kickoff it it merits penalties or ejections. Since the second get-together, referees and security are separating the two sides at midfield.

    Before heading back into the locker room, UK's players ran to the closed side of Papa John's Cardinal Stadium, again riling up fans. Even a team that's lost five straight games is coming into this one treating it like a rivalry that matters.
